John I. Yellott, Jr., Wins Junior
Award For Article On
Supersaturated Steam

With an article titled Supersaturated Steam, John I. Yeloltt, Jr., alumnus of the Johns Hopkins University
and present instructor in mechanical
engineering at the University of
Rochester, won the Junior Prize offered by the American Association of
Mechanical Engineering.
The article has been printed once
in a Japanese magazine and several
times in English periodicals, but the
award was based on technical value
alone.

De Lamar Lectures to be given next
year have been announced by the
School of Hygiene and Public Health.
The first of this series of lectures will
be given January 15, by Dr. Leslie T.
Webster, associate member of the
Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. Dr. Webster's topic will be
"Host Response to Infectious Agents."
On February 19, Harrison P. Eddy,
Boston civil engineer, will deliver the
second talk on "Municipal Sanitation
and the Public Health."
Dr. F. Maurice McPhedran, assistant professor of the Henry Phipps Institute of the University of Pennsylvania, will discuss "The Parthogenesis
of Tuberculosis in Relation to its Public Health Economics" on March 19.
Schedule Scammon
The final lecture will be delivered
on an early date in April by Dr. Richard E. Scammon, Dean of Medical
Sciences at the University of Minne-

The De Lamar bequest also supports the American Journal of Hygiene, published under the auspices
of the School of Hygiene and Public
Health.

Captain Holtzman Secures
Runner-up Position; Team
Nosed Out By Stonewalls
Led by Captain Paul Holtzman, the
Johns Hopkins cross-country team
captured second place in the South
Atlantic A. A. U. meet held last Sunday. The squad was just beaten out
for first honors by the Stonewall
Democratic Club, who finished with
a total of 39 points, as compared to
The Baltimore Crossthe Jays' 43.
Country Club was third with 47 markers, while the Chester Pleasure Club
scored 81 points.
Holtzman, competing in his last
meet for the Black and Blue, ran one
of the best races of his career, finshing second behind Bill Agee, nationally known star. Agee won the six-mile
grind in the time of 35:30, while
Holtzman completed the course in
36:09, defeating 31 experienced harriers.
Carl Sholtes also turned in an excellent performance, gaining fifth position in a strong field, while Leonard
Emmert captured tenth for the Black
and Blue. Brown and Clark completed
the first five Jay runners, placing
14th and 15th, respectively. Other
Hopkins harriers to finish were Lyman, 16th; Castelle, 29th; and Schultz,
32nd.
This is the closest the Black and
Blue has ever gotten to winning the
annual classic, and it marks the end
of a very successful season, in which
the Jays defeated their old rival, Virginia, for the first time in 3 years.
Perhaps their greatest achievement,
however, was the capturing of the
Fred Buchholz collegiate trophy in the
Washington District Championships,
held on Thanskigiving Day. The Black
and Blue runners defeated harriers
from Catholic U., Maryland, and St.
John's, and unofficially were low point
scorers of the whole field, which included the Baltimore Cross-Country
Club and several Washington organizations.
Tonight, the team will hold a banquet at the home of Coach Hamilton.
Manager Severn stated that all former runners and all those connected
with the sport are welcome to attend,
and should get in touch with him concerning it.

The railroads appreciate the enthusiastic responses of students
and faculty to the "College Special" fares which combine economy with the great advantages of rail travel—safety,speed,comfort and convenience.

you came to school this Fall, the coupon is good returning home

John I. Yellott, Jr., Wins Junior
Award For Article On
Supersaturated Steam

With an article titled Supersaturated Steam, John I. Yeloltt, Jr., alumnus of the Johns Hopkins University
and present instructor in mechanical
engineering at the University of
Rochester, won the Junior Prize offered by the American Association of
Mechanical Engineering.
The article has been printed once
in a Japanese magazine and several
times in English periodicals, but the
award was based on technical value
alone.

De Lamar Lectures to be given next
year have been announced by the
School of Hygiene and Public Health.
The first of this series of lectures will
be given January 15, by Dr. Leslie T.
Webster, associate member of the
Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. Dr. Webster's topic will be
"Host Response to Infectious Agents."
On February 19, Harrison P. Eddy,
Boston civil engineer, will deliver the
second talk on "Municipal Sanitation
and the Public Health."
Dr. F. Maurice McPhedran, assistant professor of the Henry Phipps Institute of the University of Pennsylvania, will discuss "The Parthogenesis
of Tuberculosis in Relation to its Public Health Economics" on March 19.
Schedule Scammon
The final lecture will be delivered
on an early date in April by Dr. Richard E. Scammon, Dean of Medical

Captain Holtzman Secures
Runner-up Position; Team
Nosed Out By Stonewalls
Led by Captain Paul Holtzman, the
Johns Hopkins cross-country team
captured second place in the South
Atlantic A. A. U. meet held last Sunday. The squad was just beaten out
for first honors by the Stonewall
Democratic Club, who finished with
a total of 39 points, as compared to
The Baltimore Crossthe Jays' 43.
Country Club was third with 47 markers, while the Chester Pleasure Club
scored 81 points.
Holtzman, competing in his last
meet for the Black and Blue, ran one
of the best races of his career, finshing second behind Bill Agee, nationally known star. Agee won the six-mile
grind in the time of 35:30, while
Holtzman completed the course in
36:09, defeating 31 experienced harriers.
Carl Sholtes also turned in an excellent performance, gaining fifth position in a strong field, while Leonard
Emmert captured tenth for the Black
and Blue. Brown and Clark completed
the first five Jay runners, placing
14th and 15th, respectively. Other
Hopkins harriers to finish were Lyman, 16th; Castelle, 29th; and Schultz,
32nd.
This is the closest the Black and
Blue has ever gotten to winning the
annual classic, and it marks the end
of a very successful season, in which
the Jays defeated their old rival, Virginia, for the first time in 3 years.
Perhaps their greatest achievement,
however, was the capturing of the
Fred Buchholz collegiate trophy in the
Washington District Championships,
held on Thanskigiving Day. The Black
and Blue runners defeated harriers
from Catholic U., Maryland, and St.
John's, and unofficially were low point
scorers of the whole field, which included the Baltimore Cross-Country
Club and several Washington organizations.
Tonight, the team will hold a banquet at the home of Coach Hamilton.
Manager Severn stated that all former runners and all those connected
with the sport are welcome to attend,
and should get in touch with him concerning it.
